original_title: Sri Lanka president, Tamil National Alliance MPs disagree on police powers
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Legislators representing Sri Lanka’s Tamil-majority northern and eastern provinces and President Ranil Wickremesinghe were unable to reach a consensus on the inclusion of police powers in the full implementation of an India-backed devolution mechanism.

At a meeting held at the Presidential Secretariat in Colombo on Tuesday July 18, opposition Tamil National Alliance (TNA) parliamentarian M A Sumanthiran said excluding police powers in the implementation of the 13th amendment to the constitution would not amount to a meaningful devolution of power.

Noting that former President Mahinda Rajapaksa had made three separate joint-statements with the government of India recognising the need to fully implement the 13th amendment including police powers, Sumanthiran said the steering committee of the constitutional assembly at the previous parliament had arrived at some measure of agreement on the way forward.
“So now to go back and say [there is gong to be an] exception with police powers…  It doesn’t seem meaningful at all,” he said.

Responding to the MP, President Wickremesinghe said while he agrees with Rajapaksa that there should be full implementation of the 13th amendment, there was an outcry when Wickremesinghe’s administration had proposed the same.

“Firstly, I’m Ranil Wickremesinghe, not Ranil Rajapaksa. I’m not bound by – I’m not going to say what President Rajapaksa did, but I do go along with him that there has to be full implementation of the 13th amendment. But in the discussion we had earlier, when I mentioned full implementation, there was a big outcry and we decided that we’ll go ahead and take up police powers later. So you have to decide on that,” said Wickremesinghe.

Sumanthiran said the president’s previous deadline of February 04 for finding a lasting solution to Sri Lanka’s ethnic conclusion was not met and the new deadline of July 31 also does not seem realistic. The TNA does not wish to be party for such a solution, he said.
“But we’re not opposed to you implementing any of these things,” he added, referring to other proposals.

Wickremesinghe said: “I didn’t say I’m going to implement everything. I said the proposal will be given to you before July 31. Now I have given the proposals. Question is do you want to support it or not?”
The president asked Sumanthiran to submit his views to a committee of ministers that includes Ministers Susil Premajayantha and Prasanna Ranatunga.

Jaffna district MP an former Northern Province Chief Minister C V Vigenswaran who had in February welcomed the president’s overture to the Tamil community, said at Tuesdya’s meeting that his position is that anything that strengthens the 13th amendment and will see its implementation is the need of the hour. President Wickremesinghe asked the MP to submit his views to the ministerial committee as well.

“The minister’s committee will start sitting in about two weeks’ time. Those of you who want to come can come. In the meantime, I’ll speak to other party leaders and find out their views,” said Wickremesinghe.
Notably, Tuesday’s round of discussion was ahead of an official visit to India by the president.

The 13th amendment to Sri Lanka’s constitution emerged from the controversial Indo-Lanka Accord of 1987 as a purported solution to the worsening ethnic conflict, four years after war broke out. Provincial councils came in the wake of this amendment, though land and police powers have yet to be devolved to the provinces as originally envisioned. Both Sinhalese and Tamil nationalists have historically opposed the amendment, the former claiming it devolved too much, the latter complaining it didn’t devolve enough.

A full implementation of the amendment would see land and police powers devolved to the provinces, a development that is not likely to garner support from Sri Lanka’s more nationalist-oriented parties including sections of the ruling Sri Lanka Podujana Peramuna (SLPP). In February, sections of Sri Lanka’s Buddhist clergy took to the streets against the proposed full implementation of the constitutional amendment.

A statement from the President’s Media Division said Tuesday evening quoted him as saying that he had already put forth a “comprehensive proposal to address the problems faced by the people in those regions and it is up to the Tamil parliamentarians whether to take it forward or not”.

“Ultimately, the president underscored that the full enforcement of the 13th amendment can only be achieved if all party leaders in the parliament agree to a comprehensive devolution of powers,” the statement said. (Colombo/Jul19/2023)
